paper_metadata.title: MAIN TEXT
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: The paper discusses the TTR gene variants S52P and T119M, focusing on their roles in transthyretin amyloidogenesis and associated clinical implications.

individual_records.phenotype_details: most aggressive phenotype of hereditary systemic TTR amyloidosis
individual_records.evidence_sentence: The extremely rare S52P TTR variant is the least stable TTR variant and causes the most aggressive phenotype of hereditary systemic TTR amyloidosis.

functional_data.summary: S52P TTR is less stable and more susceptible to proteolytic cleavage, leading to amyloid fibril formation.

variants.additional_notes: S52P variant is linked to severe clinical outcomes.
key_quotes: The extremely rare S52P TTR variant is the least stable TTR variant and causes the most aggressive phenotype of hereditary systemic TTR amyloidosis.

individual_records.evidence_sentence: The non-amyloidogenic and protective T119M variant is neither cleaved nor generates fibrils under these conditions.

functional_data.summary: T119M variant is resistant to proteolysis and does not form fibrils.

variants.additional_notes: T119M variant is considered protective against amyloidogenesis.
key_quotes: The non-amyloidogenic and protective T119M variant is neither cleaved nor generates fibrils under these conditions.

extraction_metadata.notes: All relevant data was extracted from the main text.
